junit@yahoogroups.com wrote:
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "J. B. Rainsbe=
rger"
> <jbrains@r...> wrote:
> 
>> The design /is/ the point of the discus=
sion.
> 
> No, it is *a* point of discussion.  It's healthy to ask the
> or=
iginal poster if this design is really necessary, but if
> they say "yes", =
then we should just move on to solving their
> problem and not patronize th=
em on how pure their architecture is.

You are probably more referring to m=
y posts than to J.B.'s.

If the OP said something along the lines of "I kno=
w the design is
suboptimal, but I currently can't do something about it", I=
 would have
accepted that and concentrated on solving his testing problem u=
sing Junit.

But I didn't understand him to say that. Instead I understood =
him to say
something more along the lines of "my design is quite good the w=
ay it is,
and it is strange that Junit doesn't support testing it very well=
."

From the little I know about his design, I still doubt that the design =
is as
good as it could be, and I thought it might be of value to point that=
 out,
and perhaps even get an interesting discussion going on that issue. I=
f I
sounded patronizing that way, I appologize - that wasn't my intent.

> =
In real life, faulty or imperfect designs are the norm.

Sure. That's one r=
eason unit testing is so valuable: it makes some of the
imperfectionism mor=
e visible, so that we can work on it.

> If a framework forces you to chang=
e your design to be useful,
> you can bet that most companies will keep the=
ir design and
> choose another framework.

And some developers would rather=
 choose a framework that is lightweight than
one that better supports scena=
rios they don't strive for anyway. It's nice
that we have a choice, isn't i=
t?

Take care, Ilja
